sn9.11:4.1: At one time one of the mendicants was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.
sn9.11:4.2: Now at that time that mendicant, during their day’s meditation, was thinking bad, unskillful thoughts, that is:
sn9.11:4.4: The deity haunting that forest had compassion for that mendicant, and wanted what’s best for them. So they approached that mendicant wanting to stir them up,
sn9.11:5.4: make sure your thoughts are rational.
sn9.11:6.1: Thinking about the Teacher, the teaching,
sn9.11:6.2: the Saṅgha, and your own ethics,
sn9.11:6.4: and rapture and bliss as well, no doubt.
sn9.11:6.5: And when you’re full of joy,
sn9.11:6.6: you’ll make an end to suffering.”
sn9.11:7.1: Stirred up by that deity, that mendicant came to their senses.
